docs.lead_paragraph: Black patients with early stage lung cancer are less likely than whites to undergo life-saving surgery and as a result are more likely to die of their disease, doctors are reporting today. Dr. Peter B. Bach, a lung specialist at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan and an author of the report, said the reason for the disparity was unknown. But Dr. Bach said it was not because of the differences between the races in socioeconomic status, insurance, general health or access to medical care. Among the possible causes, the researchers said, are that doctors do not recommend surgery to blacks as often as to whites or that blacks more often refuse surgery, perhaps because of poor doctor-patient communication.

headline.main: Racial Discrepancy Is Reported in Surgery for Lung Cancer

docs.snippet: Black patients with early stage lung cancer are less likely than whites to undergo life-saving surgery and as a result are more likely to die of their disease, doctors are reporting today.     Dr. Peter B. Bach, a lung specialist at Memorial...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senior Republicans in Congress proposed today to restore some of the money they cut from Medicare in 1997, but they said they had no plans to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly this year. Under immense pressure from the health care industry, the Republican lawmakers said they would soon pass legislation to increase Medicare payments to hospitals, nursing homes, outpatient clinics, home health care agencies, doctors and health maintenance organizations.

headline.main: Republicans Would Restore Some 1997 Cuts in Medicare

docs.snippet: Senior Republicans in Congress proposed today to restore some of the money they cut from Medicare in 1997, but they said they had no plans to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly this year.    Under immense pressure from the health care...

docs.lead_paragraph: On the morning of the 1996 Presidential election, Sharon Denny showered and dressed. She drove to the polling place, an elementary school in her neighborhood in Houston, and on the way she gave herself a pep talk. ''This is so important,'' she told herself. ''And it makes such a difference to our country. You have got to go vote.'' But standing in line for the voting booth, Ms. Denny, who is 51, grew anxious. What if she got inside and did not know what to do? What if she punched the wrong holes? She broke into a cold sweat, she recalls, and she remembers thinking, ''This is why they don't want people with mental illness to vote, because what if I get up there and I really want to vote for Bill Clinton and I don't, I end up voting for Dole?''

headline.main: Gentle Drive to Make Voters Of Those With Mental Illness

docs.abstract: Mental Health Voter Empowerment Project is trying to create nationwide constituency of people with mental illness by locating potential voters, registering them, educating them about mental health issues and making sure they get to polls on Election Day 2000; whether voter project will be embraced by politicians remains to be seen, especially in climate where they are under pressure to respond to highly publicized incidents of violence involving mental illness; issue is complicated by fact that many politicians have only recently become aware of mental health as political issue; Ken Steele, who spent 35 years in state hospitals with diagnosis of schizophrenia, started voter empowerment project in New York City in 1994; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton directed Federal officials today to visit America's schools and enroll children in a health insurance program that he said had fallen far short of his original goal of providing coverage to five million youngsters. ''It is simply inexcusable that we're sitting here, and have been, with the money for two years to provide health insurance to five million kids, and 80 percent of them are still uninsured,'' Mr. Clinton said at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Pediatrics.

headline.main: President Urges Government To Reach Uninsured Children

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, speaking at meeting of American Academy of Pediatrics, directs Federal officials to visit America's schools and enroll children in health insurance program that he says has fallen far short of his original goal of providing coverage to five million youngsters; Congress created Children's Health Insurance Program in 1997; it provides $24 billion over five years and total of $39 billion over 10 years, but states have used less than 25 percent of money made available so far (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Victory for Patients'' (editorial, Oct. 9): The Dingell-Norwood proposal passed by the House would not stop health plans from exercising their authority to review decisions by doctors. But the proposal would require plans to provide evidence supporting their decision if they overrule a doctor.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Don't Lose In Patient Bill

docs.abstract: Sen Edward M Kennedy letter holds Dingell-Norwood proposal passed by House would not stop health plans from exercising their authority to review decisions by doctors; also contends legislation does not create new rights to litigate

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Pakistan's Prime Minister Ousted in Military Coup The military removed Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif in an apparently bloodless coup hours after Mr. Sharif fired the chief of the Army. The Army chief, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, said the military had ousted Mr. Sharif to stop any further politicization or destabilization of the military. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: State workers could extend their health care benefits to unmarried or same-sex partners under a proposal to go before an arbitrator later this month. The State Employees Bargaining Agent Coalition, which negotiates the pension and health benefits of about 43,000 state employees, says benefits for domestic partners are a matter of civil rights.

headline.main: Arbitrator to Rule on Giving Health Benefits for Partners

docs.abstract: State workers in Connecticut could extend their health care benefits to unmarried or same-sex partners under proposal that will go before arbitrator in late Oct; Gov John G Rowland opposes proposal (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fletcher Lokey drove 90 minutes to hear former Senator Bill Bradley, a Democratic candidate for President, speak at a high school in southern New Hampshire last week, and he was not disappointed. ''I was electrified,'' he said afterward. But when asked which of Mr. Bradley's policy positions he liked best, Mr. Lokey, 50, paused, then conceded that he could not think of one. He said he liked Mr. Bradley, a former basketball star, mainly because of his personality, which struck him as honest and sincere.

headline.main: Appeal of Bradley's Style May Hide Potential Pitfall

docs.abstract: Disaffected Democrats and independents who care deeply about character are attracted by folksy style of Democratic Presidential hopeful Bill Bradley, and have propelled his campaign from near obscurity into real contention; for Bradley's sole Democratic rival, Vice Pres Al Gore, inability of such voters to pinpoint his accomplishments, or even policy positions, indicates his support remains skin deep; aides say steady dose of criticism will move voters away from Bradley; guided by such strategy, Gore and surrogates have stepped up attacks on Bradley's character, integrity and voting record; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The debate leading up to the House vote last week to expand patients' rights was punctuated by a stream of health care horror stories. Last Wednesday, for example, Representative Sheila Jackson-Lee, Democrat of Texas, rose to tell the story of ''little Steve Olsen,'' a boy whose brain damage was misdiagnosed at a San Diego Hospital.

headline.main: Health Care Horror Stories Are Compelling but One-Sided

docs.abstract: Debate leading up to recent House vote to expand patients' rights was punctuated by stream of health care horror stories, some of questionable veracity, that were collected and aggressively distributed by several interest groups that supported legislation; difficult twist in debate was fact that complicated personal tragedies have two sides, both of which were rarely presented (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DONNA BRAZILE, who was just named Al Gore's new campaign manager, did not supply a terse, ''that was a long time ago, in another country'' response when asked about the night she stepped down from another Presidential campaign, Michael Dukakis's in 1988. She had agreed to resign after making some way-out-of-school comments prodding reporters to check out some rumors about Vice President George Bush.

headline.main: Gore's Confident Campaign Manager, Penance Complete

docs.abstract: Public Lives column profiles Donna Brazile, Vice Pres Al Gore's new Presidential campaign manager; photo (M)
